item.description: MoCBs are of two types: a thematic list of links to CBs, i.e. act as a virtual folder a sequential list of links to CBs (step-by-step script/instruction) for the execution of a process for a person (role) or machine.
Tool: merging Content Boxes into MoCB. The result is a finished instruction or scenario. More details at in_progress/MoCB. Processes.
in_progress/Raw/Automation: development of an algorithm/script based on an instruction or scenario.
Forging: Raw1 processing. Notes are polished, compressed, and taken out in Zettels. I highly recommend to stick to Progressive Summarization: A Practical Technique for Designing Discoverable Notes ↩︎
Assembling: merging/grouping Zettels by 5Ws into Content Boxes by topic (catalogue).
Raw is unstructured, written down thoughts, ideas and sketches in theirs PKBs by team members1. Notes can be stored in Google Docs, Evernote, Obsidian, etc.

Workflow KFM is based on a sequential processing workflow and modular information structuring. Modularity is the process of breaking up incoming texts into minimal logical units, from which texts are then assembled.
Ask Why every time you start a project. More than once. It will help at first materialize your idea in words.
What is the very first question you should ask during project requirements collection for your project to define the scope.
Remember Who your stakeholders are: team, client, sponsor, etc. Who ultimately benefits when your project is completed?
Sometimes When is the most critical question. You will fail even if you do everything right but at the wrong time.
Where will your project be done? Where will it be delivered? With today’s global and dispersed environments, this question is not as simple as it may seem!
Ask How only when all core questions have been answered. This is where the methods, best practices, tools and techniques get deployed… but not until you have answered in detail the 5 Ws first!
When writing a thought, I advise keeping it within 100-200 words: that’s about five notes in the size of a tweet.
Following the 5Ws, one of the values1 is written to note tags in YAML format: [opening, who, what, when, where, why, how, closing] Find the source of the current note on Google Drive as an example.
I create Content Boxes according to the 5Ws: opening – introduction, description what why who when where how closing – conclusions, links, related opening and closing are auxiliary.

During The Experiment, I decided to keep a length note limit equal to the tweet size1: 280 characters without links The character limit allows being laser-focused on one thought and keeps Content Boxes straightforward and minimal.
The Knowledge Base has three levels: Zettels Content Boxes: Zettels containers Map of Content Box: Content Boxes outliners Each of them has its own set of tags.
Each block is represented by one or more Zettels. I recommend adhering to the structure and section order of the 5Ws1.
Adhering to PKM practices solves the problem that KBs remain unclaimed in many companies. In addition, you have to include the use of KB in daily work.

How create a map of WRIO business processes1 with a breakdown into scenarios to understand how to improve according to TRIZ: add valuable or remove detrimental in_progress/Raw/Dashboard as a single entry point unification of processes for the possibility of automation community feedback for further improvements Sensitive processes and data will not be publicly available.
